item.title: A “Scope, Simulation and Story” approach to identify future spatial development scenarios
item.dc:creator: Ben Black
Orlando Roman
Jan Kwakkel
Bryan Adey
item.description:
Scenario planning often qualitatively develops storylines. These scenarios are usually depicted in a 2 × 2 scenario matrix, where it is challenging to define, for example, the drivers of change to consider in the axes and the boundaries between scenarios. In this qualitative approach, simulation models are typically used as evaluation tools only after the scenarios are generated. This approach is commonly known in the literature as “Story and Simulation”.

This study introduces a “Scope, Simulation, and Story” approach, which has the potential to enhance scenario planning by informing the development of scenarios through computational modelling. Thus, we can integrate participatory processes, spatial development simulation models, and spatial analysis to define scenario boundaries that reflect spatial patterns. We applied this method to simulate spatial development in the Canton of Zurich for 2050 using a cellular automata Land Use Cover Change (LUCC) model.

item.title: Reproducible Research with R and Quarto: Workflows for data, projects and publications
item.dc:creator: Ben Black
Benjamin Black
Manuel Kurmann
Nivedita Harisena
Maarten Van Strien
item.description:
At the Landscape 2024 conference organised by the Leibniz-Centre for Agricultural Landscape Research (ZALF) in Berlin, Germany, I gave a masterclass on Reproducible Research with R and Quarto.

This is a topic I am very passionate about and was a great opportunity to bring together a lot of practical knowledge that I have developed over the last few years.

In line with it’s theme, I wanted to make the content of the masterclass as open and accessible as possible, so I created a dedicated website for it using Quarto: https://blenback.github.io/R-for-Reproducible-Research

The website contains all the materials for the masterclass, including the slides and practical exercises. Also because the Github repository for it is public you can also see the source code that underlies it. It was a lot of work but I learned a lot along the way and overall I am really happy with the result.

item.title: Negotiating scenarios of a desirable ecological infrastructure for Switzerland
item.dc:creator: Ben Black
Sergio Wicki
Benjamin Black
Nathan Külling
item.description:
In September, I had the pleasure of contributing a joint presentation, with colleagues from the ValPar.CH project, for the 4th Swiss Landscape Congress in Tramelan, Switzerland. This conference was fairly unique as it strived to bring together not just academics but also practice-oriented professionals and stakeholders from various fields related to the landscape in Switzerland. Our contribution,demonstrated how the different methods that we have employed in our research can offer insights into decision-making regarding the implementation of an ecological infrastructure in Switzerland that achieves it’s intended purpose of safeguarding biodiversity and ecosystem services whilst also being socially acceptable.

item.title: Normative scenarios for effectively mitigating biodiversity loss
item.dc:creator: Ben Black
Benjamin Black
Adrienne Grêt-Regamey
Paula Mayer
item.description:
In August, I was invited to contribute a virtual presentation to the Foresight Training for Anticipatory Adaptation in the Hindu Kush Himalaya event, organised by the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) in Dhulikhel, Nepal.

In my presentation I shared some of our practical experiences from developing normative scenarios for landscape change in Switzerland and Peru and how such scenarios can be operationalized in simulation models to identify locations for conservation areas to effectively mitigate biodiversity loss but also the trade-offs that certain strategies may incur.

item.title: Normative scenarios of landscape change for Nature-Positive futures in Peru
item.dc:creator: Ben Black
Benjamin Black
Adrienne Grêt-Regamey
item.description:
At the World Biodiversity Forum in Davos, Switzerland, I had the pleasure of presenting early results of the NASCENT-Peru scenario creation workshops that took place in May and June 2024.

This was a great opportunity to showcase the project to researchers from around the world and highlight the importance of scenarios depicting positive futures for landscape development from the perspective of local stakeholders.

We also had the opportunity to meet with the teams of the other projects funded by SwissRE who are doing similar work in different regions of the world. It was inspiring to see the diversity of approaches and goals that each project hopes to achieve.
